comments.commentBody: Perhaps one, two or a few of the biggest facts are listed in the "President's" Tax Returns.
Or a 9-11 type of panel is as good or better?

While it is not wrong to meet with foreigners, quite the opposite, it has a potential to broaden your view of the world, it is simply wrong to lie about it under oath.

So far there is no proof that Russia has had a hand in the elections, but there are some issues that are much more of a problem and that is the involvement of Russian money in Trump's business which makes him susceptible to blackmail.
Trump has repeatedly used Russian money, e.g. in Canada, to fund his business.
Money that was supplied by Russian business people like e.g. Alexander Shnaider or Eduard Shifrin of the Midland Group with very close ties to the Russian government.

And that is where Trump and his team are vulnerable to no end.

Trump is the Manchurian Candidate.

Get over the old ethics, everyone. In this new era, lying is merely a competency test. The administration is learning a lot from the Russians on how to manage the country, so the contacts are merely mentoring sessions.

And do not miss the stories of what happened to Russian dissidents. Who knows how long it will be before daring US journalists somehow wind up dead.

Beauregard: "Oh I clearly misspoke." No, you lied! Enough with the southern charm. Can't wait until Trump's tax returns, released under subpoena in the next year, show that the impetus of Trump's love for Russia is not Putin but instead the need to placate the Russian oligarch-connected banks that he owes money to by alleviating the economic sanctions.

You nailed it Gail. Keep the southern bigot in office and tied up in knots for the next 4 years, if Trump is still around then. The alternative would be to replace him with another bigot who is less provocative.

You have to wonder how long Trump's billionaire buddies are going to want to hang around the disgusting administration. Presumably they get shunted around the country for 2 or 3 speeches a week and do very little else. If I was a billionaire at age 65-75, I could find better use for my time.

This beehive of activity had a purpose. It came directly from Trump. The purpose was to support and advise the Russians, via Wikileaks, what and when to release fuel for the anti-Hillary email popularizers who knew this would make her constantly vulnerable.

With Republicans in Congress turning a blind eye toward the Sessions scandal, if it later transpires that Sessions and Flynn were acting as Trump intermediaries to obtain Putin's help in rigging the election, then it will appear to most everyone that the GOP has allied itself with the prime enemy of American democracy. At that point the GOP will become the second-most popular party in Moscow and the third-most popular party in Washington.

I'll close with a short Watergate quiz.

What was the principal lesson of Watergate?
a) Birds of a feather flock together.
b) A word to the wise is sufficient.
c) Wake up and smell the coffee.
d) Pride goeth before a fall.
e) You reap what you sow.

Answer: f) All of the above!
`If the entire offensive line is limped off of the field, then the quarterback is a prisoner of the oval office. It's a start.

As much as I admire Senator Franklin ("He's good enough, he's smart enough, and by golly, people -like me- like him"), I feel he should not get his shorts in a bunch over Russian meddling in the election. After all, the US has made influencing and over-turning elections in other countries into an art form. That said, Jeff Sessions must resign and go back to his position as a senate garden gnome. But I'm left wondering just what the Russian Ambassador to the US was doing at the Republican convention (in Cleveland) anyway. I mean, why would you invite an obvious spy to your convention? Was he picking up a payment?

Speaking of little white lies, "Clinton did something far worse. He did not just “sit on his hands”: he deliberately stalled the efforts of others to intervene, and went so far as to deny the genocide in order to avoid being pressured to stop it."

"But Clinton’s claim not to have fully understood the situation is a lie."Timothy Longman is professor of political science and international relations at Boston University.

No big deal. Black Lives Matter. What? How many Rwandans died because Clinton turned his back on them? 1, 2, 3? Then he lied. Not to worry. Our free press is diligently seeking the Big stories.

Trump slipped up and inadvertently spoke the truth. The other day he called the Russia investigations  "a witch hunt", blaming the democrats, now he calls it "a ruse". I think the Donald overheard someone on his staff saying that delaying a response on the Russian deal was the smart thing to do. The Democrats and the press were so centered on the Russians that Trump could deregulate to his hearts content. "We're fooling the fake media, it's a ruse Donnie". Trump wants that "it's a ruse"quote as a souvenir.

Sessions' problems are two-fold: he lies under oath and he is a clumsy liar.
Watch the video. He didn't say "I did not have communications with the Russians."
He said: "and I didn't have — did not have communications with the Russians."
He stumbled at the very moment he told the lie.
Nervous and unskillful liars often give themselves away. Sessions' stumble at the moment of untruth reveals he knew he was lying as he spoke.

I thought we would never have a national scandal so horrifying (and riveting) as Watergate. How on earth could an American President become so corrupt?

I swear, these guys are beginning to make Richard Nixon look like an amateur.

Jeff Sessions should just go away, for the good of the GOP, "president" trump, America and himself. I really can not understand this administration. If I were president, regardless of party, I would chose qualified people who were not extreme in the history or outlooks. Trump has done just the opposite, and to what benefit? If he wants to reward the people who sucked up to him make them postmaster someplace.

What to do? Investigate, reveal, and let the chips fall where they may. And if he's guilty of no crime other than those against decency, logic, and justice, we're stuck with this manifestation of the common American plague of male devolution.
As long as the GOP gets its tax cuts, Dear Leader can do almost anything.  No tax cuts?  They'd turn on him tomorrow, especially as their Manchurian Candidate, Pence is in place.
Being ill-informed, I guess, I wonder why a Russian Ambassador goes to a GOP convention. And does such a foreign representative also go to the one officiated by the Democrats?
It's about to become business as usual.  European elections are coming.

Sessions must go. He can do the honorable thing and resign or he can be removed. But go he must.  Perhaps Jeff Sessions can set a precedent for the entire illegitimate administration including Donald Trump.

Seriously too late to be able to do anything 'honorable'. He doesn't deserve his first name of 'Jefferson' - and I don't like to think of him as anybody's Beauregard either. What an appalling little-minded man. Get him out of there asap.
But then - who's next? Another just like him?

There's only one reason why Clinton didn't meet with Russia, because the Republicans would've jumped all over her and brought up the atrocious uranium deal the Clintons made  with Russia through their Canadian partner. Just one more reason amongst many, why Clinton never would have won the election.

A big "Hiss" to Jeff Sessions is what I'd recommend, Gail. That's "Hiss" as in Alger Hiss, and Sessions deserves no better treatment than Congress offered Hiss.

Ironically, Sessions answered a question that Sen. Franken hadn't asked. Franken had actually asked Sessions how, as AG, he might handle the news that someone, anyone, in the Trump campaign had had contact with the Russians.

Instead, Sessions leaped to his own defense -- Had he been coached to say this? -- and denied that he himself had had any such contacts.

I don't think it was an accident. And lying to Congress is a big no-no. Just ask Bill Clinton, whom they impeached over a more innocuous parsing of questions and answers (and relating to a less serious subject than the security of our national elections).

Don't you think integrity is important? He was applying for the job of top law enforcement officer in the country and he lied to the senators who were to decide whether to confirm him about a matter of national importance. That is perjury.

Bill Clinton's lie about an affair, while offensive, was not an issue of national security. And for that he was impeached. How about some reasonable balance in our political positions and conversations.

All these contacts with the Russian ambassador might have the following reasons:
A. Putin has something unsavory to blackmail Trump, thus Trump kept blowing kisses at him.
B. Trump wanted Putin's help to win the election and learn from him how to establish an authoritarian government.
C. Trump wants to please Putin, so Putin would not confiscate Trump's properties in Russia.
D. Trum and his minions were simply too arrogant to think that they would never be found out.

Only less than two months, Trump's administration is embroiled in one scandal after another. The media he attacked should keep a close eye on these people relentlessly, because our democracy is at great peril. By the way, Sessions should resign, we cannot have an AG who lied under oath.

The Trump team is so incompetent they didn't realize that all telephone conversations and email would be recorded and stored. Now it's just a matter for some great emerging journalists and special prosecutors to bring them to life.

Trump must know with all of his extensive ties to Russia the game is just about over. No wonder he's going back to Mar a Lago for another weekend.
